SubTopics: Use sentence-level context as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
What is the meaning of the word PLUNGING in paragraph 2 of the passage from Amazing Animals: Dolphins?

A.Choice: breathing

B.Choice: chewing

C.Choice: diving

D.Choice: racing

Content: Which detail from paragraph 2 BEST helps the reader understand the meaning of the word PLUNGING?

A.Choice: “... inhale quickly ...”

B.Choice: “... back into the water.”

C.Choice: “... two to four times a minute ...”

D.Choice: “... their surroundings ...”

SubTopics: Use text features and search tools (for example: key words, sidebars, hyperlinks) to locate information relevant to a given topic efficiently.
Content: In the passage from Amazing Animals: Dolphins, the information is organized using headings. Write the letter of each fact about dolphins on the correct line under each heading.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Select choices to correctly complete the sentences about the information from Amazing Animals: Dolphins.
Because dolphins do not have gills, they :DD-1: .
As they reach the surface, dolphins must first :DD-2: .
Only after that can dolphins :DD-3: .

1:A.Choice: cannot inhale above the ocean surface

1:B.Choice: cannot get oxygen from the water

1:C.Choice: do not need oxygen to stay alive

2:A.Choice: keep their body temperature the same

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
What is the meaning of the word PREY as it is used in paragraph 6 of the passage from The World's Smartest Animals: Dolphins?

A.Choice: an animal caught by another animal for food

B.Choice: a special kind of food eaten by some whales

C.Choice: an animal that can live underwater

D.Choice: a part of the body of some whales

Content: Which detail from paragraph 6 BEST helps the reader understand the meaning of the word PREY?

A.Choice: “... by swallowing big mouthfuls of water.”

B.Choice: “... filter tiny ocean creatures out of the water ...”

C.Choice: “... animals such as dolphins, orcas, porpoises ...”

D.Choice: “... animals are hunters.”

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
How does the story in paragraphs 1 and 2 in the passage from The World's Smartest Animals: Dolphins support the idea stated in the passage's title?

A.Choice: It shows that certain types of dolphins are more clever than other types of dolphins.

B.Choice: It shows that dolphins are both quicker and braver than human beings.

C.Choice: It shows that dolphins can figure things out and solve problems.

D.Choice: It shows that dolphins and great white sharks do not get along.

Content: Which sentence from paragraph 2 BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “This amazing event happened in New Zealand in 2004.”

B.Choice: “The swimmers weren't protected by a team of brave lifeguards, however.”

C.Choice: “Their rescuers were seven bottlenose dolphins!”

D.Choice: “The dolphins seemed to understand that the swimmers needed help.”

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast the most important points and key details presented in two texts on the same topic.
Content: Today you read passages from Amazing Animals: Dolphins and The World's Smartest Animals: Dolphins. Think about how some of the ideas in the passages are different.
Write an essay that contrasts the important details in the passages. Use specific details and examples from BOTH passages to support your ideas.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
In paragraph 12, what does Bean mean when she says “it was just sort of an emergency”?

A.Choice: She is saying they could not help going into Mrs. Trantz's garden because it looked like a fun adventure.

B.Choice: She is claiming that a serious problem made it necessary for them to break Mrs. Trantz's rule.

C.Choice: She is trying to convince Mrs. Trantz not to take her garden so seriously all the time.

D.Choice: She is arguing that she had no idea that going into Mrs. Trantz's garden was wrong.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Ivy and Bean climbed over the stone wall and dropped down onto her lawn.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “It was very long, and there was no way to go around it.” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “But Mrs. Trantz was home.” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “She smiled in an unfriendly way.” (paragraph 13)

SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
How does paragraph 13 add to the ideas in paragraph 4?

A.Choice: by showing Bean changing her mind about what she said

B.Choice: by proving that Bean was wrong about what she said

C.Choice: by providing an example of what Bean mentioned

D.Choice: by solving a problem that Bean mentioned

Content: Which other paragraph builds on paragraph 4 in the same way?

A.Choice: paragraph 5

B.Choice: paragraph 9

C.Choice: paragraph 11

D.Choice: paragraph 12

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
What is the central message of the passage?

A.Choice: Children can avoid trouble by doing what they are told.

B.Choice: Children need to stay out of other people's yards.

C.Choice: Adults care too much about following silly rules.

D.Choice: Adults need to earn children's respect.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'Closer, please, Bernice.'” (paragraph 7)

B.Choice: “'Well, Ivy, children are not allowed in my garden.'” (paragraph 11)

C.Choice: “'Because Bernice does not seem to be able to remember it by herself.'” (paragraph 11)

D.Choice: “'If you were sorry, you wouldn't keep coming into my garden when I have asked you not to.'” (paragraph 13)

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (for example: their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Write the letters for THREE phrases in the box labeled Mrs. Trantz that describe how Mrs. Trantz feels in the passage. Phrases can be used only once.

A.Choice: scared of the girls

B.Choice: angry at the girls

C.Choice: unsure about what to do

D.Choice: protective of her yard

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
What does BELLOWED mean as it is used in paragraph 6 of the passage from “Don't Eat Me!”?

A.Choice: whispered quietly

B.Choice: jumped clumsily

C.Choice: moved painfully

D.Choice: yelled loudly

Content: Which detail from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “I tiptoed up behind the frog ...” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “I dropped it ...” (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: “This frog screams to defend itself ...” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “The predator is surprised ...” (paragraph 10)

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Which sentence is a main idea of the passage from “Don't Eat Me!”?

A.Choice: Children should not be afraid of frogs because they are harmless.

B.Choice: Frogs have developed many ways to defend against threats.

C.Choice: Frogs all over the world are in danger from predators.

D.Choice: Even scientists need to be careful around frogs.

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'I'll shine my flashlight in its eyes so it won't jump.'” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “'Even if you could still see the frog, you wouldn't want to catch it again, right?'” (paragraph 13)

C.Choice: “Years ago, my seven-year-old daughter was helping me count rococo toads in Argentina.” (paragraph 17)

D.Choice: “Just because frogs and toads don't have shells or claws or beaks, don't think they can't protect themselves.” (paragraph 21)

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs in a text (for example: comparison, cause/effect, first/second/third in a sequence).
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Read the sentence from paragraph 1 of the passage “Cloaked in Starlight.”
:box:Bobtail squids must taste good.
Which sentence BEST explains this statement?

A.Choice: Bobtail squids eat the food that sea creatures like.

B.Choice: Bobtail squids look like they are full of flavor.

C.Choice: Bobtail squids make ink that predators like.

D.Choice: Bobtail squids are prey to many animals.

Content: Which sentence from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “During the day, barracuda try to find and eat them.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Then, the squid disappears a different way.” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “The predator bites the inky squid shape.” (paragraph 4)

D.Choice: “Inside the pockets, the bacteria eat, grow, and shine brightly.” (paragraph 7)

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Based on the passage from “Don't Eat Me!” and the passage “Cloaked in Starlight,” select whether each detail describes frogs, squids, or both.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Use information gained from illustrations (for example: maps, photographs) and the words in a text to demonstrate understanding of the text (for example: where, when, why, and how key events occur).
Content: The passage from “Don't Eat Me!” and the passage “Cloaked in Starlight” describe how animals protect themselves. Write a response that explains how the illustrations and the text support this idea. Support your response with details from BOTH passages.

SubTopics: Use sentence-level context as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
What does the word DEVICES mean as it is used in paragraph 9?

A.Choice: clothing

B.Choice: places

C.Choice: problems

D.Choice: tools

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST helps the reader understand the meaning of the word DEVICES?

A.Choice: “Scuba divers wear wet suits.” (paragraph 8)

B.Choice: “The insides of submersibles are heated.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “... must be aware of how much air is left ...” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “... use underwater pressure gauges.” (paragraph 9)

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
What makes submersibles important for the study of ocean life?

A.Choice: how quickly they can get to the top of the water

B.Choice: how much equipment they can hold

C.Choice: how many divers they can carry

D.Choice: how far down they can explore

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Scuba divers sometimes make deep dives.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “... several thousand feet or meters underwater.” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “These devices show how much air is in the air tanks.” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “... how long it will take a diver to reach the surface safely.” (paragraph 9)

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Select choices to correctly describe the ocean floor and dry land.

As divers have gone deeper and deeper into the ocean, they have learned many new facts about how the ocean and the land are the same and different. For example, there are large, flat places on the ocean floor that look the same as :DD-1: on dry land.
They have also learned that :DD-2: come up from the ocean floor and can reach all the way to the ocean's surface. The tops then become :DD-3: .
Finally, divers have learned that the ocean floor has :DD-4: that are much like volcanoes.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Which sentence BEST describes why divers are important for science?

A.Choice: Divers can use wet suits and other equipment to dive deeper underwater.

B.Choice: Divers are able to gather information about life and land underwater.

C.Choice: Divers are able to look at types of fish that glow underwater.

D.Choice: Divers can use different air tanks when they go underwater.

Content: Which TWO sentences from the passage BEST support the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Scuba divers use tanks filled with air to breathe underwater.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “But technical divers need special training and equipment.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “They have learned that oceans have similarities to land.” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “Deep divers also have learned a great deal about ocean life.” (paragraph 6)

E.Choice: “These tanks supply divers with enough air to breathe for about 90 minutes.” (paragraph 9)

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Select which main idea each detail best supports from the passage.

SubTopics: Distinguish the literal and nonliteral meanings of words and phrases in context (for example: take steps).
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
What does the phrase ON THE NOSE mean as it is used in paragraph 6 of “The Glockentown Clock Caper”?

A.Choice: not pleasant to hear

B.Choice: exactly correct

C.Choice: much too clear

D.Choice: bad smelling

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST helps the reader understand the meaning of ON THE NOSE?

A.Choice: Raclette hears an awful screeching noise.

B.Choice: The clock chimes at the expected time.

C.Choice: The front of the clock looks like a face.

D.Choice: Raclette looks up in surprise.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (for example: their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
In “The Glockentown Clock Caper,” what happens as a result of Raclette's talk with Professor Berg?

A.Choice: Professor Berg offers to help Raclette learn to play a musical instrument.

B.Choice: Professor Berg gives Raclette the clue that helps him solve the mystery.

C.Choice: Professor Berg tells Raclette how to become a better horn player.

D.Choice: Professor Berg gives Raclette an excuse to leave the café.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Raclette took two more thoughtful sips, then went out to meet the musician.” (paragraph 19)

B.Choice: “'I'd like to take a lesson from you, Professor,' Raclette said.” (paragraph 20)

C.Choice: “'I tell them to pick a time — the same time every day — and just make sound for 10 minutes.'” (paragraph 23)

D.Choice: “'That really develops the mouth muscles, you know.'” (paragraph 23)

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (for example: their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Select choices to complete a description of the characters in “The Glockentown Clock Caper.”
“'I'll be ruined! Who will buy a clock from anyone in the Stoppen family now?'” Stoppen says in paragraph 10. This shows he is worried that :DD-1: .
Details in paragraphs :DD-2: show that other people in the town feel much the same way. Paragraph 1, though, shows that Raclette is :DD-3: , and he :DD-4: .

1:A.Choice: the problem will hurt his business

4:A.Choice: would rather be doing something else

SubTopics: Use sentence-level context as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
What does the word CARILLON mean as it is used in paragraph 5 of the passage from The Haunted Clock Tower Mystery?

A.Choice: a huge toy made from wood

B.Choice: a machine that tells time

C.Choice: a musical instrument

D.Choice: a type of game

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST helps the reader understand the meaning of the word CARILLON?

A.Choice: “Just then the clock chimed loudly.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “'It's almost time for the evening concert,' said Ezra.” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “' ... you won't believe how big they are.'” (paragraph 4)

D.Choice: “... there were two long horizontal rows of wooden knobs sticking out.” (paragraph 5)

SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Read paragraph 4 of the passage from The Haunted Clock Tower Mystery.
:box:“Yes, that's the carillon,” Ezra said. “The bells are upstairs. We'll go up in a minute so you can see them. They're the best part — you won't believe how big they are.”
How do paragraphs 5–7 add to the ideas in paragraph 4?

A.Choice: They explain why Ezra wants to play the carillon for the children.

B.Choice: They explain how the carillon actually makes a sound.

C.Choice: They explain why the carillon's bells must be so large.

D.Choice: They explain how Ezra learned to use the carillon.

Content: Which TWO details from the passage BEST support the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “The children had never seen anything quite like the carillon before.” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “It reminded them a little bit of their upright piano ...” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “Down near the floor was a row of wooden pedals, and up above the carillon was a row of wires leading up through the ceiling.” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “'You sit on this bench to play it,' Ezra said ...” (paragraph 7)

E.Choice: “The children heard a bell chime above them.” (paragraph 7)

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: Select the statement that is a central message of “The Glockentown Clock Caper”. Then select the statement that is a central message of the passage from The Haunted Clock Tower Mystery.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (for example: their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: You have read “The Glockentown Clock Caper” and the passage from The Haunted Clock Tower Mystery. Write an essay that describes the two main characters, Detective Raclette and Benny. Be sure to support your ideas with details from BOTH passages.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
What does the word IMPRESSED mean as it is used in paragraph 2 of the passage?

A.Choice: amazed

B.Choice: confused

C.Choice: disappointed

D.Choice: satisfied

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST demonstrates why the narrator was IMPRESSED?

A.Choice: “It was fun going to Melody's house.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “She had the best room.” (paragraph 1)

C.Choice: “... it's a kind of wallpaper, not painted.” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “... I could see a tiny line down the side.” (paragraph 4)

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (for example: their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Select the BEST descriptions of the characters based on information in the passage.
Melody's opinions about the narrator's drawing in paragraph 4 show that Melody :DD-1: .
Benji's drawing of himself feeding the monkeys in paragraph 5 shows that he :DD-2: .
The narrator's question in paragraph 8 shows that she is :DD-3: .

1:A.Choice: has an idea for a new drawing

3:A.Choice: unsure about food in Melody's house

3:B.Choice: wishing she was at her own house

3:C.Choice: tired of eating nuts and fruit

SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
How do paragraphs 7 and 8 build on what happens earlier in the passage?

A.Choice: They show how the narrator changes from feeling excited about the special things in Melody's house to missing the things she is used to at home.

B.Choice: They show that although the narrator is disappointed at first by the food in Melody's kitchen, she learns why it is important to try new things.

C.Choice: They show that although the narrator likes being Melody's friend, she would rather have Melody come play at her house.

D.Choice: They show why the narrator should not have judged Melody's brothers before she got to know them better.

Content: Which TWO sentences from the passage BEST support the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “One whole wall of her room was a picture of jungle animals.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “'It came that way,' Melody said.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “Benji and Felix weren't too bad, for boys.” (paragraph 4)

D.Choice: “Mom told me Melody's mother was very 'nutritious.'” (paragraph 7)

E.Choice: “'Don't you have any candy?' I asked.” (paragraph 8)

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Select the central message of the passage.

A.Choice: Different families do things in different ways.

B.Choice: Things are not always what they seem to be.

C.Choice: Eating healthy food is important.

Content: Select TWO details that support the central message from Part A.

W.Choice: “There was a lion staring in the grass ...” (paragraph 1)

X.Choice: “' ... let's go get some real bananas.'” (paragraph 5)

Y.Choice: “... Mom always had cookies or chocolate ...” (paragraph 7)

Z.Choice: “... Melody didn't have any of those things.” (paragraph 7)
